item.title: Why the shack dwellers' movement poses a threat to the ANC - Al Jazeera English
item.description:
Why the shack dwellers' movement poses a threat to the ANC  Al Jazeera English

New York, United States - S'bu Zikode, the leader of a shack dwellers' movement in Durban, South Africa, said he received a tip-off from police in July that he was being targeted and his life was under threat. Since then, the Abahlali baseMjondolo (AbM) organiser has been living underground, away from his family, between safe houses. "I had been receiving threats from a number of local ANC councillors via AbM members and others, warning me not to step into their communities … the ANC have basically created no-go zones," Zikode told Al Jazeera on the sidelines of an event in New York on Sept...

item.title: South Africa: murders surge by more than 7% in a year - The Guardian
item.description:
South Africa: murders surge by more than 7% in a year  The Guardian

Murders in South Africa have surged by more than 7% in the last year, with more than 20,000 people killed in 12 months, new official statistics have shown. The country has long struggled to with violent crime. The new figures, released on Tuesday, showed that 57 people were murdered daily over a 12-month period between April 2017 and March 2018. “It borders close to [a] war zone while there is a peace,” said Bheki Cele, the police minister. Related: Murders of farmers in South Africa at 20-year low, research shows He added: “We haven’t reached a state of lawlessness in South Africa and we w...

item.title: Fears of vote rigging as South Africa’s ANC elects new leader - Financial Times
item.description:
Fears of vote rigging as South Africa’s ANC elects new leader  Financial Times

As the battle to determine who leads the African National Congress entered its final stages, Cyril Ramaphosa warned that vote buying was a “new disease” plaguing South Africa’s ruling party. “People are being approached with loads of money, some of it between 50,000 to 100,000 [rand] per delegate” the deputy president told a South African radio station last week. Mr Ramaphosa has good reason to be worried about vote buying ahead of an ANC conference this weekend where more than 5,000 delegates will elect a new party leadership. He is in a two-horse race with Nkosazana Dlamini-Zuma, the form...
